The method as set forth in claim 1, characterized in that the dehydrogenating/hydrogenating function of the catalyst of step (a) is selected from among transition metals from the groups VB, VIB, VIIIB, IB, primarily Cu, Ni, V, Cr, Mo, W, Fe, Ru, Co, Pt, and Pd, that are present in the catalyst in the form of oxides, carbonates, halides, phosphates, carbides, nitrides, or even as reduced metals.

12. The method as set forth in claims 1 and 11, characterized in that the basic function of the catalyst of step (a) is selected from among alkali and alkaline earth metals of groups IA and IIA in the form of oxides, hydroxides, phosphates, carbonates, supported or not supported on heterogeneous supports such as aluminas, hydrotalcites, basic zeolites, silicas, silica-aluminas, activated carbon, mixed oxides, spinels, or basic clays such as limestone, dolomite, magnesite, sepiolite, olivine, in addition to anion exchange resins, metal oxides such as ZnO, and basic organometallics.
13. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 and 12, characterized in that the catalyst operating step (a) is preferably Cu supported on K-doped alumina.

14. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 to 13, characterized in that the catalyst operates at a temperature in the range from 150 to 550° C., preferably from 200 to 500° C., and more preferably in the range from 300 to 450° C.

15. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 to 14, characterized in that the catalyst operates with a space velocity (LHSV) of from 0.1 to 10 h−1, preferably from 0.5 to 5 h−1, more preferably from 0.5 to 2 h−1.
16. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 to 15, characterized in that the catalyst operates at a pressure of from 5 to 200 bar, preferably from 10 to 100 bar, more preferably from 20 to 60 bar.

17. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 to 16, characterized in that the catalyst operates with a feed having a volumetric ratio of hydrogen (H2) per oxygenated compound containing six carbons from 0 to 10 mol H2/mol, preferably from 0 to 5 mol H2/mol, and more preferably from 0 to 2 mol H2/mol.

18. The method as set forth in claims 1, 11 to 17, characterized in that the catalyst operates at a molar ratio of the oxygenated compound containing one carbon to that of the oxygenated compound containing six carbons of at least 1 to 20 mol:mol, preferably from 2 to 16 mol:mol, more preferably from 6 to 9 mol:mol.
19. The method as set forth in claims 1 and 11 to 18, characterized in that the unreacted methanol in the product of step (a) is recovered and returned to step (a) of claim 1.

20. The method as set forth in claims 1 and 11 to 19, characterized in that the content of hydrogen (H2) used when CO is employed as an oxygenated carbon compound is greater than or equal to 2 mol, and the content of hydrogen (H2) is greater than or equal to 3 mol when the compound with one carbon is CO2.
21. The method as set forth in claims 1 and 11 to 20, characterized in that the gaseous effluent from step (a) containing H2, CO, and CO2 is returned to step (a) of claim 1.

22. The method as set forth in claim 1, characterized in that the deoxygenation catalyst of step (b) is a dehydration catalyst with acidic sites, such as aluminas, zeolites, silica-aluminas, hydrotalcites, mixed oxides, spinels, sulfonic resins, ZrO2, sulfated zirconia, and activated carbon.

23. The method as set forth in claim 1, characterized in that the deoxygenation of step (b) is a hydrodeoxygenation reaction in the presence of H2 and a hydrotreatment catalyst, with sulfides of Mo or W, promoted by Ni or Co, and supported on solids such as alumina, silicas, silica-aluminas, zeolites, hydrotalcites, mixed oxides, spinels, MgO, TiO2, ZnO, CeO2, phosphates, sulfonic resins, ZrO2, sulfated Zr, carbon, and activated carbon.

24. The method as set forth in claim 1, characterized in that the deoxygenation of step (b) is a hydrodeoxygenation reaction in the presence of H2 in which the hydrodeoxygenation catalyst is a partially reduced metal oxide supported on a porous solid such as MoO3, or other metals such as RuO2, IrO2, PdO, Rh2O3, SnO2, ZnO, VO2, TiO2, CeO2, CuO, Ag2O, and Au2O3 supported on a porous solid.

25. The method as set forth in claim 1, characterized in that the hydrodeoxygenation catalyst has partially reduced metals in its composition that are selected from among Pt, Pd, Ru, Ni, Cu, Mo, W, Co, Ir, Rh, Au, Ce, Fe, Mn, Ga, Pb, and Bi, alone or in mixtures, and supported on solids such as alumina, silicas, silica-aluminas, zeolites, hydrotalcites, mixed oxides, spinels, MgO, TiO2, ZnO, CeO2, phosphates, resins sulfonic compounds, ZrO2, sulfated Zr, carbon, and activated carbon.
26. The method as set forth in claims 1, 23 to 25, characterized in that the hydrodeoxygenation catalyst support is oxophilic, as is the case with alumina, TiO2, and ZrO2.
